aviHFy4IzjML5uPo4pCSrA.text: A nice little restaurant under Raffles City Shopping Centre.  Servers were pretty good and prompt.  They use an iPad for you to enter what you want and voila it pops out from the kitchen.I ordered the lunch special consisting of gyoza, karaage chicken, miso soup and rice for about S$9.90.  It took a while to get the food to me but it was an indication the food was made fresh.  I wasn't disappointed too much as everything did not taste overly salty.  It was done well but not great.  I did enjoy the meal and it was filling.I would come back in a pinch.

photos.caption: Photo of Osaka Ohsho - Singapore, Singapore. Good food
Photo of Osaka Ohsho - Singapore, Singapore. Side wall
Photo of Osaka Ohsho - Singapore, Singapore. Front cashier

BApR5HDQwDRHW9cXR9zNjA.text: The ambience is quite clean and casual. The iPad you use to order from has a cover that is gross and honestlyy quite as dirty as a menu. It's a little hard to get attention from the waiter but they are helpful. The signature dish tenshin han is really filling. It's a huge omelette with rice in it. Nothing else. It's a BALL of a omelette. It's like our Singapore National Stadium. Its sauce is a slightly thick gravy with a "savory sweet and sour" taste to it. Also ordered a mix fry Togi. The egg and sauce was good. Meat was average. The fried prawns were all soaked and all soggy. I could get this kind of quality food from my polytechnic food court. Gyoza was fine. Surprisingly it retained its heat for some time. Most or all of the ala carte dishes here comes without rice. So if you're someone like me who needs rice, it doesn't make sense to eat ala carte here. Their ala carte seems reasonabke here and that may beckon you to enter. Say I ordered my mix Togi it's just egg and the fried prawn and chicken. No rice. Rice alone is $3 so it's ultra no value to order rice. Over here, never look at the ala carte price. Always look at the set price. Many good foreign restaurants who set up shop here, they just import a brand with a story from say, Japan that has quality and care and does the opposite while milking all it's worth here in Singapore. Here is an example of it.

photos.caption: Photo of Osaka Ohsho - Singapore, Singapore. Mix fry Toji

gd5INmWCCG6rHrDAYg0yag.text: It's average food, something to fill the stomach. The gyoza is decent. At least it is not oily and the skin is crispy. Go for the gyoza, not the best but it's way better than the ramen I had. The ramen broth is so plain it will take time for you to get used to it. It has a bit of alkaline taste from the noodle, followed by a soup made of salt though it's not overly salty like other places. The noodle is of the hard chewy variety and the two pieces of char siew are thick and not melt in mouth tender. Half boiled egg is hard. If you're used to the nicer ramen then skip this. You will be thoroughly disappointed. They charge $1 for a glass of water!

photos.caption: Photo of Osaka Ohsho - Singapore, Singapore. Ramen set $11.90

a4CO6IOlfisABg516llTuw.text: First time here. Food quite good. The Fuwatoro Tenshin Han set was good. Gyoza was very good but the ramen was average. The rice with salmon was good but took quite awhile to serve. Decent place for a meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Osaka Ohsho - Singapore, Singapore. Fuwatoro Tenshin set.

CZ_qHVeQoGqAx55gMqWJcw.text: Ordered the Gyoza set to try. The gyoza are so so. Uses iPad for ordering which is quite convenient. Not much of servicing needed. I have tried better food in other Ohsho. So this is definitely nothing special. But it is good enough if you are hungry.If there is a choice, most probably will not choose to visit again

zgZZGDSwMKahBsDKVKiYuA.text: Cheap and cheerful Japanese eatery specialising in gyoza. Have eaten here a few times and the food is always decent. The sets are good value as they come with egg drop soup, 3 gyoza and a generous bowl of rice plus a savoury dish. I like the gyoza which have the requisite crunchy bottoms and are well seasoned. One complaint I have is the last meal I had there everything was lukewarm. It was probably pre-prepped for the dinner rush. So watch it if you're eating at peak hours - avoid dishes that look like they could be preprepped.

photos.caption: Photo of Osaka Ohsho - Singapore, Singapore. Chicken with tartar sauce set
Photo of Osaka Ohsho - Singapore, Singapore. Chilli crab set

x-dvVuce21PH0E16b-YGDg.text: You would be an idiot to eat ramen here. Of course you have to go for the gyoza, it's their speciality after all. Pricing is quite reasonable at 6 for $3.90 and 12 for $7.80.I went for the Fuwataro Tenshin Han $13.90 set that also included 3 pcs of gyoza. Boy it sure looked fluffy and I guess there must have been 4-6 eggs in there. The portion was too much for me, I couldn't finish it at all. Would recommend 2 to share this.My friend had the fried rice which looked pretty good but was different from the rice in the tenshin Han. Will definitely give that a try next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Osaka Ohsho - Singapore, Singapore. Fuwataro Tenshin Han Set $13.90

UqgdmSGu1hhzFI_31vaqEQ.text: Unless you are super hungry and the surrounding better dining options are taken, otherwise don't even bother having food here.It tastes more like Chinese food than Japanese food. I had the ebi with runny egg dish that tastes rather off. Gyoza was so so. Service was alright as well. It is just the food that does not make the cut.

nv_B1Qf-mxkbjZ-jBjfXUA.text: This is "Japan's handmade gyoza specialist since 1969".  12 gyozas are $8, and you can also order 6 gyozas. The gyozas are light, not too greasy, with lots of vegetables and garlic. Thin-skinned, but pan-fried so it's crispy on one side. They're not super-juicy, but the kind of gyozas where you can eat a dozen and feel "healthy" and still eat more.  They have a perfectly pre-mixed vinegar with soy sauce and vinegar.  We ate there 2 days in a row because the price was right, and the gyozas were yummy and felt healthy.It's not just gyozas. They have a set menus available: chili pork, ramen, fried chicken, Japanese egg and rice.  (About $10-$15 / set) A mix of Chinese dishes and Japanese dishes. Some sets give 3 gyozas, while other sets give 6. The rice is some special rice from Japan, and it is better than the white rice you usually get in restaurants.They now charge $1 for for a large bottle of tap water (used to be free), and they've taken a lot of items off their menu (mapo eggplant instead of mapo tofu.) There's more deep-fried stuff  on their menu, so it's not as healthy as before.

photos.caption: Photo of Osaka Ohsho - Singapore, Singapore. Gyoza and egg with rice. Ate half of it before remembering to take a picture.

bg05KPXcAV9qoAdYKfTOhg.text: Very good japanese food, very lively and nice udon noodles. Very solid would come back here

8YVkwuQosI74bpKAGWcwaQ.text: OMG... Pls do not come here... We have food that's literally soaked in oil! Ordered fried ika which had pieces not coated well with flour and were having an oil bath by the time they arrived.I ordered the black vinegar chix set whilst my bf ordered the Saba set. Mine was oily and gooey whilst my bf said his feels like it's been fried in the hospital... Very dry and hard. And oh the gyozas... We prayed that it wld be their saving grace since it was supposed to be their signature... Man were we disappointed! So frustrated to have wasted our calories and money on bad food!

lXYqWSMJyhIb5abdNp9_8A.text: Japanese food's elegance is in it's simplicity. It seems so simple - but in practice, it's so, so easy to screw up. In short, Osaka Ohsho, has screwed it up.The ramen is awful- as in really, really bad. The noodles themselves were overcooked, soft to the point where there was virtually no texture. The broth was bland, and the egg and cha-siu were mediocre. The gyoza which came with the meal ($15 set meal) were also a disappointment. The skin wasn't crispy, the skins of the gyoza stuck to one another, while the gyoza themselves fell apart when you picked them up (the part of the dumpling where it's crimped to seal were ripping apart when you picked it up). They also had one dish which sounds utterly amazing - Soft Shell chilli crab ($10). Imagine the possibilities with this dish, it's mind boggling! But alas, this could-be-epic dish comes up far short of it's potential. Poorly fried crab (i.e greasy) with way too much better, covered in a sauce which taste like sweet and sour sauce: yuck. My friend didn't even finish it after a bite or two. Given the options which are available at the plaza - skip this one.

FcR864wBpTTfWafhRKl4nA.text: Japanese fast food of course - while it looked pretty crowded, we only had to wait for around 5-10 mins in the queue, and one of the waiters took our order then, so by the time we sat down, our food came in about 5 mins. Quick and good, especially in this place which is chockful of office workers who need to grab a quick bite.The star dish here apparently is their gyoza and it comes with whatever set that you order. Pretty decent, quite tasty without the additional dumpling sauce, fairly meaty as well without too much veg and stuff in it which I never like. Ordered their Thursday special, the set with fried chicken and double-cooked pork. Fried chicken was a tad salty but tasty, the double-cooked pork (what on earth is double cooked? is that a good thing?) was more veggies than pork, and the set came with a bowl of sticky white rice and an eggy-carroty soup and 3 gyoza. My friend ordered the fried rice set - the fried rice was also quite tasty and hers came with 5 gyoza and soup.Decent place for a quick lunch!

mEvMXOMPy7g9RlZbQSWWwA.text: The Fuwatoro Tenshin Han was basically fluffy omelette rice with a thick layer of gravy poured on it. This tasted great and is a must have as its not commonly found in other Japanese establishments.The Gyokai Ramen tasted not too bad but not outstanding either.The Gyoza 6 pieces comes with the sets. Its understandable how they are famed for these gyozas. These are slightly pan-fried and tasted great with each bite.This place serves Houji Cha, which is roasted green tea, as opposed to most other restaurants serving Ocha. Nonetheless, this tasted fragrant and refreshing.

s_gUJnW26IkV48tbLZKEfQ.text: Japanese street food. I don't understand the excitement about the gyoza. Overly minced meat, the texture was too mashed, with no bite. The omelette rice porridge tasted like baby food.
